mentions.context: Pl@ntNet provides the possibility to integrate specific flora previously collected by (amateur) botanists using dedicated semi-automatic tools.
Pl@ntNet is an existing smartphone and web-based application that allows identifying plant species on images [16].
Pl@ntNet provides generic functionality to recognize plants that can be used by anyone, but also dedicated applications that focus on specific flora in e.g.
Pl@ntNet is straightforward to use.
Pl@ntNet is an automated visual identification system that integrates various novel approaches in handling and classifying imagery [9].
Pl@ntNet is built on the combination of a deep learning image classification model and a generalist content-based image retrieval method (for details see [9,16]).

Pl@ntNet users have already contributed 605 242 crop photos (as of 16 November 2021) from around the world to the Crops application.
Pl@ntNet uses up to date Latin taxonomy to classify at species level.
In Pl@ntNet, being one species, these cultivars are all in the same class, notwithstanding their different visual appearances.

In fact, plant identification can be difficult, even for a trained botanist, and benchmarked datasets are needed to improve algorithms (see for example the public dataset created by Pl@ntNet on anemones, https://plantnet.org/en/2021/03/30/aplntnet-dataset-for-machine-learning-researchers/).

This type of long-term evaluation makes it possible to quickly detect major advances in terms of performance and to accelerate their integration into operational production systems such as Pl@ntNet.

Novice, amateur, and expert botanists have been collecting and revising millions of geo-tagged and timestamped photographs of plant species with apps such as Flora Incognita [7], iNaturalist [8], and Pl@ntNet [9].
